entities.name: Selective Breeding
entities.description: Selective breeding is when breeders choose which dogs reproduce based on specific traits. This process has led to the distinct features that English Bulldogs are known for, but has also made them susceptible to illness.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: English Bulldogs are a breed of dog known for their distinct features, such as a pushed-in nose and a low, sturdy body. These features, while endearing, can unfortunately lead to a variety of health issues.

entities.name: Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome
entities.description: Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome (BAS) is a condition common in animals with shortened facial features, like English Bulldogs. This condition can lead to breathing problems, chronic discomfort, exercise intolerance, and difficulty eating.

entities.name: Difficulty Breathing
entities.description: Difficulty breathing is a common issue in English Bulldogs, largely due to genetic abnormalities caused by selective breeding. This can manifest as gasping, snoring, or heavy panting.

entities.name: Elongated soft palate
entities.description: Occurs in Brachycephalic dogs where the soft palate extends into the airway, making it harder to breathe. This creates more resistance in the airway and can lead to edema, or inflation of the palate, causing the airways to narrow.

entities.name: Stenotic Nares
entities.description: Condition where the dog has pinched or narrow nostrils that struggle to take in air. This condition is known from the signature Bully snore and snort. If it becomes a health hazard, surgery may be recommended to widen the nostrils.

entities.name: Pneumonia
entities.description: Occurs when the lower respiratory tracts become irritated, usually when the dog inhales vomit or regurgitation. This can cause severe damage to the lungs and surrounding tissue.

entities.name: Temperature Regulation
entities.description: Brachycephalic dogs have trouble panting effectively, which is what regulates their body heat. Signs of overheating include excessive panting, heaving while panting, discolored flappy tongue, exhaustion while trying to breathe, odd throat noises, and foaming of the mouth.

entities.name: Overheating Prevention and Treatment
entities.description: To prevent overheating, ensure a ventilated place for the dog to sleep and monitor their behavior in weather above 80 degrees. If symptoms of overheating are observed, cool down the dog with a cold-water bath or a hose, give them plenty of cold water to drink, bring them inside and put them in front of a fan, and increase airflow by spreading their fur.

entities.name: Allergies
entities.description: Bulldogs have the most allergies of any breed due to their genetic makeup abnormalities.

entities.name: Food allergies
entities.description: Food is a sensitive point for bulldogs. Generic food brands with low-quality ingredients often trigger allergies in English Bulldogs. Symptoms include itchy skin, fecal issues, excessive shedding, and ear infections.

entities.name: Skin allergies
entities.description: One cause of skin infection in English Bulldogs is allergic dermatitis. Dogs may be sensitive to flea bites or environmental allergens like pollen and mold.

entities.name: Thyroid and Heart Disease
entities.description: Health issues from selective breeding have also caused problems in the internal organs.

entities.name: Hyperthyroidism
entities.description: Hyperthyroidism is when the thyroid slows down, which causes decreased production of thyroxine, the hormone responsible for regulating the metabolism.

entities.name: Pulmonary Stenosis
entities.description: Pulmonary Stenosis is a heart deformity most often found in English Bulldogs. It blocks blood flow and can lead to heart failure or even death.

entities.name: Cancer
entities.description: Bulldogs are especially susceptible to cancers like lymphoma and mast cell tumors.

entities.name: Lymphoma
entities.description: Lymphoma is a blood-borne cancer of lymphocytes, which are a specific type of white blood cell.

entities.name: Mast cell tumors
entities.description: Mast cell tumors, or MCT, are involved in your dog’s response to allergens and inflammation.

entities.name: Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome
entities.description: A common condition in animals with shortened facial features, causing breathing problems, chronic discomfort, exercise intolerance, and difficulty eating. It worsens with obesity.

entities.name: Difficulty Breathing
entities.description: A common health risk in bulldogs due to upper airway defects caused by Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome.

entities.name: Temperature Regulation
entities.description: Brachycephalic dogs have trouble panting effectively, which regulates their body heat. Overheating can occur in hot weather.

entities.name: Skin Problems
entities.description: Common in bulldogs due to their skin folds. Includes eczema, bacterial infections, hot spots, and interdigital cysts.

entities.name: Bone and Joint Disease
entities.description: Common in bulldogs due to a structural defect called chondrodysplasia. Includes canine hip dysplasia, joint and ligament injuries, and arthritis.

entities.name: Eye Problems
entities.description: Common in older bulldogs. Includes cherry eye, brachycephalic ocular disease, and dry eye.

entities.name: Head Shakes
entities.description: Not described in the content.

entities.name: Selective Breeding
entities.description: Selective breeding is when breeders choose which dogs reproduce based on specific traits. Some select for abilities, others for physical characteristics. This process was used in the 17th century for bull-baiting, a cruel sport where dogs would be sent in one at a time to take down a bull. Breeders needed a dog that was low to the ground, could bite with immense force and was stubborn enough never to let go. Thus, breeders selected the Old English Bulldog for this sport. This narrow selective process caused the Old English Bulldog health problems that continue to affect bulldogs today.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: English Bulldogs are wrinkly, adorable dogs full of personality. Their pressed noses make them look eternally grumpy, which only makes them more endearing. Yet, the problem with this distinct look is that it’s the result of selective breeding, which can, unfortunately, put them at risk for serious health complications.

entities.name: Health Issues
entities.description: English Bulldogs are prone to health issues due to selective breeding. These health issues may include everything from difficulty breathing to bone defects.

entities.name: Head Shakes
entities.description: A condition where the dog's head starts vibrating uncontrollably, sometimes violently enough to be mistaken for a canine seizure. This condition usually results from low blood sugar and stress, but sometimes there can be more pressing medical issues that require immediate attention.

entities.name: Allergies
entities.description: Bulldogs have the most allergies of any breed due to their genetic makeup abnormalities. These can be food allergies or skin allergies.

entities.name: Thyroid and Heart Disease
entities.description: Health issues from selective breeding have also caused problems in the internal organs. Hyperthyroidism is when the thyroid slows down, which causes decreased production of thyroxine, the hormone responsible for regulating the metabolism. Pulmonary Stenosis is a heart deformity most often found in English Bulldogs.

entities.name: Cancer
entities.description: Bulldogs are especially susceptible to cancers like lymphoma and mast cell tumors.

entities.name: Selective Breeding
entities.description: Selective breeding is when breeders choose which dogs reproduce based on specific traits. This process has led to the distinct features that English Bulldogs are known for, but has also made them susceptible to illness.

entities.name: Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome (BAS)
entities.description: A condition common in animals that have shortened facial features that give them the pushed-in nose. Bulldogs have been bred to have relatively short muzzles and noses and, because of this, the throat and breathing passages in these dogs are frequently undersized or flattened. This causes breathing problems, chronic discomfort, exercise intolerance, and difficulty eating.

entities.name: Difficulty Breathing
entities.description: A common health issue in English Bulldogs due to upper airway defects caused by Brachycephalic Airway Syndrome. Genetic abnormalities caused by selective breeding significantly impact the dog's airways.

entities.name: Elongated soft palate
entities.description: A condition in Brachycephalic dogs where the soft palate extends into the airway, making it harder to breathe. This can lead to edema, or inflation of the palate, causing the airways to narrow.

entities.name: Stenotic Nares
entities.description: A condition where the dog has pinched or narrow nostrils that struggle to take in air. This can lead to the signature Bully snore and snort. If it becomes a health hazard, surgery may be recommended to widen the nostrils.

entities.name: Pneumonia
entities.description: A condition that occurs when the lower respiratory tracts become irritated, usually when the dog inhales vomit or regurgitation. This can cause severe damage to the lungs and surrounding tissue.

entities.name: Temperature Regulation
entities.description: Brachycephalic dogs have trouble panting effectively, which is what regulates their body heat. Signs of overheating include excessive panting, heaving while panting, discolored flappy tongue, exhaustion while trying to breathe, odd throat noises, and foaming of the mouth.

entities.name: Skin Problems
entities.description: English Bulldog health problems symptoms include skin infections and irritation. These can include eczema, bacterial infections, hot spots, acne, and interdigital cysts.

entities.name: Bone and Joint Disease
entities.description: English Bulldogs have a unique build due to a structural defect called chondrodysplasia. This increases the likelihood of having bone and joint problems such as canine hip dysplasia, joint and ligament injuries, and arthritis.

entities.name: Eye Problems
entities.description: Old English Bulldog health problems include vision issues such as Cherry Eye, Brachycephalic ocular disease, and Dry eye.

entities.name: Head shakes
entities.description: A condition where the dog's head starts vibrating uncontrollably, sometimes violently enough to be mistaken for a canine seizure.

entities.name: Allergies
entities.description: Bulldogs have the most allergies of any breed due to their genetic makeup abnormalities. These can be food allergies or skin allergies.

entities.name: Food allergies
entities.description: Food is a sensitive point for bulldogs. Generic food brands with low-quality ingredients often trigger allergies in English Bulldogs. Symptoms include itchy skin, fecal issues, excessive shedding, and ear infections.

entities.name: Skin allergies
entities.description: One cause of skin infection in English Bulldogs is allergic dermatitis. Dogs may be sensitive to flea bites or environmental allergens like pollen and mold.

entities.name: Thyroid and Heart Disease
entities.description: Health issues from selective breeding have also caused problems in the internal organs. These can be thyroid or heart diseases.

entities.name: Hyperthyroidism
entities.description: Hyperthyroidism is when the thyroid slows down, which causes decreased production of thyroxine, the hormone responsible for regulating the metabolism.

entities.name: Pulmonary Stenosis
entities.description: Pulmonary Stenosis is a heart deformity most often found in English Bulldogs. It blocks blood flow and can lead to heart failure or even death.

entities.description: Lymphoma is a blood-borne cancer of lymphocytes, which are a specific type of white blood cell.
